page.title: 06EASINGTON TYTHE BARN
page.content: {TYTHE BARN }Perhaps the oldest Building in Easington after the church is the tythe barn.This barn has no recorded history although its position only a few yards from the parish church suggests that it was buit as the church barn late in the middle ages sometime during the 14th Century. {STRUCTURE}The barn is four and a half bays long,with storage bays flanking a central bay in which threshing (by hand flail) was done.The aisle and gable walls are of brick;not original. {ROOF}The roof is thatched with Norfolk reeds.It is hipped at both ends with collars and ties of good scantlings supported on a plate.The barn is the last example of the Holderness traditional timber and thatch building.Behind the barn is an Octagonal Horse Walk in brick.
